Unlike acomputer virus, it does not need to attach itself to an existing program.cite webDifference between a computer virus and a computer wormhttp://scienceline.ucsb.edu/getkey.php?keyUSCB SicienceLineWorms almost always cause at least some harm to the network, even if only by consumingBandwidth (computing)bandwidth, whereas viruses almost always corrupt or modify files on a targeted computer.

Many worms that have been created are designed only to spread, and do not attempt to change the systems they pass through. However, as theMorris wormandMydoomshowed, even these "payload free" worms can cause major disruption by increasing network traffic and other unintended effects. A "Payload (software)payload" is code in the worm designed to do more than spread the wormit might delete files on a host system (e.g., theExploreZipworm), encrypt files in aransomwareattack, or send documents viae-mail. A very common payload for worms is to install aBackdoor (computing)backdoorin the infected computer to allow the creation of a "zombie computerszombie" computer under control of the worm author. Networks of such machines are often referred to asbotnetsand are very commonly used bye-mail spamspamsenders for sending junk email or to cloak their website's address.Cite newshttp://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/businesstechnology/2001859752_spamdoubles18.htmlThe Seattle TimesBusiness & Technology: E-mail viruses blamed as spam rises sharplyFebruary 18, 2004TiernanRaySpammers are therefore thought to be a source of funding for the creation of such worms,Cite newshttp://www.wired.com/news/business/0,1367,60747,00.htmlCloaking Device Made for SpammersWiredOctober 9, 2003BrianMcWilliamscite webhttp://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/afp_world/view/68810/1/.htmlUnavailableand the worm writers have been caught selling lists ofIP addressesof infected machines.cite webhttp://www.heise.de/english/newsticker/news/44879http://web.archive.org/web/20090528002116/http://www.heise.de/english/newsticker/news/448792009-05-28http://web.archive.org/web/20090528002116/http://www.heise.de/english/newsticker/news/44879hiese onlineUncovered: Trojans as Spam Robots2004-02-212012-11-02Others try to blackmail companies with threatenedDenial-of-service attackDoSattacks.Cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/technology/3513849.stmBBC NewsHacker threats to bookies probedFebruary 23, 2004

Users can minimize the threat posed by worms by keeping their computers' operating system and other software up-to-date, avoiding opening unrecognized or unexpected emails, and runningFirewall (computing)firewallandantivirussoftware.cite webhttp://www.veracode.com/security/computer-wormComputer Worm Information and Removal StepsVeracode2015-04-04

Backdoors can be exploited by other malware, including worms. Examples includeDoomjuice, which can spread using the backdoor opened by Mydoom, and at least one instance of malware taking advantage of therootkitand backdoor installed by theSony/BMGDigital rights managementDRMsoftware utilized by millions of music CDs prior to late 2005.cite webhttp://www.pcworld.com/article/123362/sony_ships_sneaky_drm_software.htmlSony Ships Sneaky DRM SoftwarePcworld.com2005-11-012012-06-10DubiousJanuary 2010
article.heading: Worms with good intent
article.paragraph: Beginning with the very first research into worms atXerox PARC, there have been attempts to create useful worms. Those worms allowed testing byJohn Shochand Jon Hupp of theEthernetprinciples on their network ofXerox Altocomputers. TheNachi wormNachifamily of worms tried to download and install patches from Microsoft's website to fix vulnerabilities in the host systemby exploiting those same vulnerabilities.cite webVirus alert about the Nachi wormhttp://support.microsoft.com/kb/826234MicrosoftIn practice, although this may have made these systems more secure, it generated considerable network traffic, rebooted the machine in the course of patching it, and did its work without the consent of the computer's owner or user. Regardless of their payload or their writers' intentions, most security experts regard all worms asmalware.

Several worms, likeXSS WormXSS worms, have been written to research how worms spread. For example, the effects of changes in social activity or user behavior. One study proposed what seems to be the first computer worm that operates on the second layer of the OSI model (Data link Layer), it utilizes topology information such as Content-addressable memory (CAM) tables and Spanning Tree information stored in switches to propagate and probe for vulnerable nodes until the enterprise network is covered.Cite book10.1109/ISCC.2010.5546723A link-layer-based self-replicating vulnerability discovery agentThe IEEE symposium on Computers and Communications7042010Al-SalloumZ. S.WolthusenS. D.978-1-4244-7754-8
article.heading: Protecting against dangerous computer worms
article.paragraph: Worms spread by exploiting vulnerabilities in operating systems.Vendors with security problems supply regular security updatescite webhttp://www.ubuntu.com/usnUSN listUbuntu2012-06-10(see "Patch Tuesday"), and if these are installed to a machine then the majority of worms are unable to spread to it. If a vulnerability is disclosed before the security patch released by the vendor, azero-day attackis possible.

Users need to be wary of opening unexpected email,cnSeptember 2014and should not run attached files or programs, or visit web sites that are linked to such emails. However, as with theILOVEYOUworm, and with the increased growth and efficiency ofphishingattacks, it remains possible to trick the end-user into running malicious code.

AntivirusAnti-virusandAntispywareanti-spywaresoftware are helpful, but must be kept up-to-date with new pattern files at least every few days. The use of aFirewall (computing)firewallis also recommended.

In the AprilJune, 2008, issue ofIEEETransactions on Dependable and Secure Computing, computer scientists describe a potential new way to combat internet worms. The researchers discovered how to contain the kind of worm that scans the Internet randomly, looking for vulnerable hosts to infect. They found that the key is for software to monitor the number of scans that machines on a network sends out. When a machine starts sending out too many scans, it is a sign that it has been infected, allowing administrators to take it off line and check it for malware.Cite journalhttp://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/freeabs_all.jsp?isnumberSellkeS. History
article.paragraph: File:Morris Worm.jpgthumbMorris wormsource code disk at theComputer History MuseumThe actual term "worm" was first used inJohn Brunner (novelist)John Brunner's 1975 novel,The Shockwave Rider. In that novel, Nichlas Haflinger designs and sets off a data-gathering worm in an act of revenge against the powerful men who run a national electronic information web that induces mass conformity. "You have the biggest-ever worm loose in the net, and it automatically sabotages any attempt to monitor it... There's never been a worm with that tough a head or that long a tail!"Cite bookJohnBrunnerThe Shockwave RiderNew YorkBallantine Books19750-06-010559-3

On November 2, 1988,Robert Tappan Morris, aCornell Universitycomputer science graduate student, unleashed what became known as theMorris worm, disrupting a large number of computers then on the Internet, guessed at the time to be one tenth of all those connectedcite webhttp://www.paulgraham.com/submarine.html#f4nThe SubmarineDuring the Morris appeal process, the U.S. Court of Appeals estimated the cost of removing the virus from each installation was in the range of $20053,000, and prompting the formation of theCERT Coordination Centercite webhttp://www.cert.org/encyc_article/tocencyc.htmlSecurity of the InternetCERT/CCand Phage mailing list.cite webhttp://securitydigest.org/phage/Phage mailing listsecuritydigest.orgMorris himself became the first person tried and convicted under the 1986Computer Fraud and Abuse Act.cite bookDresslerJ.Cases and Materials on Criminal LawUnited States v.
